Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> GPUs were shut out by FPGAs and ASICs relatively

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> and not losing money  on power costs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> when everyone has FPGAs, you will have gained exactly zero efficiency in mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> profit wise your right

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> at geoscale

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> as eveyrone gains the same hardware it equals out

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> but if a single piece of hardware is the same price as say 10 piece of hardware, then even if profits remain the same but power costs go down then you gained something

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> so, algorithms should do a good job to make dedicated mining investments, like FPGAs better, but not crushing the non-dedicated investments, like CPUs and GPUs, to the extent they can. that supports the scalable economics AND decentralization

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> that is not stopping progress

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> algorithms that can do that ARE progress

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> you can't fully support cpu mining without hurting gpu mining and the like

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> it can only be done artificially

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> it's all relative, and they all have their strengths and weaknesses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> no more artificial than proof of work itself

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> cpu mining has strengths only if the aglo is built to use a cpu's architecture in a way that isnt' supported by gpu's

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> CPUs are ASICs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> technically everything is an asic

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> point being, PoW is about proof of work. it is arbitrary

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> as long as it proves work

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> right now, the algo "artifically" advantages FPGAs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> so, soon, it won't

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> so your saying that by manualy reducing the effectiveness of hardware you work to maintain the status quo of hardware in a way that makes the network better?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> not sure if i worded that right

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> i'm just tryin to see your pov

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> you want to keep all hardware relative to one another regardless of what they are actually capable of

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> by balancing the proof of work algorithm to leverage strengths and weaknesses of the available hardware worldwide in a way that both incentivizes dedicated mining and doesn't close the door to casual mining, i believe there is much more chance of true decentralization. just because no one is doing it well now doesn't mean it is not achievable

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> whatever they are capable of, proof of work only proves investment and interest in observing the protocol due to economic risk, nothing more

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> i look forward to seeing how it works out

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> me too üòÉ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> mining isnt an altruistic endeavor unfortuantely

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> at least pow isn't

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> if a coin you believe in is profitable then you mine it, if its not profitable then you mine something else and buy what you believe in

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> thats the reality of mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> but i hope you guys are successful with the changes and i'll definitely keep an eye out for how it comes along

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> will be curious to see how hash rates work out across the board

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> agreed to some extent. there's a thing called "speculative mining", and mining one coin just to sell it and buy another doesn't always get you the same result. when some large group of people lose financially due to factors that were both out of their control and secretly leveraged by a small group, that is quite the opposite of altruistic in a way this community prefers is eventually eliminated by not being rewarded. we prefer a system where people don't have to be altruistic, just one that rewards openness more than a covert approach.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> at the end of the day, only a small amount of miners on your network will mine a coin that isn't profitable; those that believe in the coin or those that are hoping for a pump at some point

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> otherwise it makes more sense to mine something that is profitable and buy the coin you  believe in

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> people dont mine at a loss out of the goodness of their heart

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> that's ok

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> there are lots of variables of course

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> but thats just a rough statement

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> anyways, good talkin to you..glad to hear your pov and wish you Happy Holidays!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> at least when things are more equal, we won't lose 70% of the hash power when one data center goes offline. that only happened when many who didn't have the secret FPGA algo found it no longer something they should mine and the PoW became much more centralized. we expect that to go back to a healthier state for the network

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Happy Holidays to you too!

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zawy> what CPUs are considered effective with the new POW?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <paia> I see some advantage in having higher clocked core, and probably more cache. So oveclocked xeon could be on top this time.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <paia> But there are not so big differences in performance per 1 core.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <paia> 1-2 mhs per core in general.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zawy> then I just wonder what this means ``` it is far more likely that the CPUs in those PCs will be older, rather than the newest models. With VerusHash 2.0, modern CPUs are strongly advantaged over older CPUs, and the newest, advantaged even more.```

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> @zawy I'm not the expert, but if you look at the #cpu-hashrate channel you can see the perf of CPUs presently and historically, while the hash rate will be much lower after the fork this is a good place to begin determining what's best.  Personally I'm going to utilize an i7-8700. If I was going to buy something new it would be the i9.  I'm curious to see the new numbers after the fork!  In the old hash I always got better perf from my i7 over my Xeon, but again, I'm not an expert on CPUs or the features of each when compared to each other.
